profilr
  • Reference
  • News

Profile atomic vectors or data.frames.

profile takes vectors and data.frames and returns a data.frame containing important descriptive statistics.

profile(.x)

# S3 method for numeric
profile(.x)

# S3 method for character
profile(.x)

# S3 method for data.frame
profile(.x)

# S3 method for default
profile(.x)

Arguments

.x

a vector or data.frame to be profiled.

Value

a data.frame containing important descriptive statistics.

Methods (by class)

  • numeric: Method for numeric.

  • character: Method for character.

  • data.frame: Method for data.frames.

  • default: Method for default.

Examples

# Example
profile(mtcars)
#>    .column_name .column_class .column_type .count_elements .count_uniques
#> 1           mpg       numeric       double              32             25
#> 2           cyl       numeric       double              32              3
#> 3          disp       numeric       double              32             27
#> 4            hp       numeric       double              32             22
#> 5          drat       numeric       double              32             22
#> 6            wt       numeric       double              32             29
#> 7          qsec       numeric       double              32             30
#> 8            vs       numeric       double              32              2
#> 9            am       numeric       double              32              2
#> 10         gear       numeric       double              32              3
#> 11         carb       numeric       double              32              6

profile(iris)

profile(state.name)
#>   .count_elements .count_uniques .percent_uniques .count_NULLs .percent_NULLs
#> 1              50             50                1            0              0
#>   .count_NAs .percent_NAs .count_zeroes .percent_zeros .mean_value .sd_value
#> 1          0            0             0              0          NA        NA
#>   .q0_value .q25_value .q50_value .q75_value .q100_value
#> 1   Alabama         NA         NA         NA     Wyoming
#>                                                                                  .top_5_values
#> 1 (1) Alabama [1]\n (1) Alaska [1]\n (1) Arizona [1]\n (1) Arkansas [1]\n (1) California [1]\n
#>                                                                                        .bottom_5_values
#> 1 (1) Wyoming [1]\n (1) Wisconsin [1]\n (1) West Virginia [1]\n (1) Washington [1]\n (1) Virginia [1]\n
